entry.title: Consume SAP S/4HANA Odata from SAP Datasphere
entry.content:
Hello Experts,

I have some Odata from S/4HANA Private Cloud

and I want to consume it in Datasphere

I research in some blog, it seems only ways to create generic Odata connection in Datasphere, but It seems not good if we have a lot of Odata in SAP S/4HANA

Could you please instruct me the best solution to consume SAP S4HANA Odata in SAP Datasphere

entry.content:

The “SAP_FI_HL_ProfitAndLossSemantictag” view has an filter where you can select both the financial statement version and the planning category. The planning category works, but no default value is displayed for the financial statement version. Does anyone have a solution to the following problem?

entry.title: CDS View I_GLACCOUNTHIERARCHY is empty in SAP S/4HANA (in relation to Finance Foundation in SAC)

However, this view is empty in our system. What customizing do I need to fill the view with data? Can anyone help me here?

Constant

Greetings, experts!

Sometimes we have a floating error that we cannot localize, it appears and then does not. And not only at the SAC level, but also at the Preview Analytical Model DataSphere level

often after reloading the page the problem disappears, but sometimes it appears

 

 

SAP Datasphere

entry.title: Need to Change Scheduled Job Owner in SAP Datasphere
entry.content:
Hi 

Our SAP Datasphere jobs were scheduled using the user ID of an external implementor. As the in-house SAP team has taken over, we now need to deactivate this user ID. However, doing so is halting all scheduled jobs. Business constraints also prevent us from stopping these jobs or changing the “Scheduled Owner” directly.

Is there any way we can change the Scheduled Owner for these jobs to an in-house user or the Default System User without disrupting running processes?

Please advise on the recommended approach.

entry.title: Sap Datasphere : Multiple choice Input Parameter
entry.content:
Hello,

Is it possible to configure and use in Datasphere an Input parameters that allows a "Multiple Choice" Values.

If yes, how can I do this ?

If no what would be an other possibilities ?

Thanks a lot 

Frederic

entry.title: SAP Datasphere Description field with HTML and other related styling Tags
entry.content:
How to clean a description column coming from SAP Fiori to S/4 into SAP data sphere which has hyperlink tags different types and of not having specific pattern or criteria.

i.e. One value might be just 2-3 lines description with simple html anchor tags and another can be with more than 10 lines with different HTML tags. For e.g. Anchor, some font styling tags like Init capital for each sentence, Bold, Italic, space and paragraph.

entry.title: SAP Datasphere Data Access Control Hierarchy with Directory (Insufficient Privilege)
entry.content:
Hello,

I'm facing insufficient privileges when adding a DAC Hierarchy with directory in my fact view.

I tried to keep it as simple as possible by only selecting leafs in the hierarchy with directory settings.

Yet, Im not sure why it shows a privilege error? 

Maybe someone can help out. Ive tried to add all relevant screenshots for a better understanding.

Thanks for any help,

Nina.

 

 

 

Error Message on Fact View when adding the DAC Hierarchy with Directory:

 

 

Permission Table:

 

 

DAC:

 

 

 

 

2FI_SAPCONTENT_CostCtrHierarchyView (Hierarchy with directory settings):

 

 

HRF: Cost Center Hierarchy Directory (DIM):

CostCenterHierarchy --> Hierarchy Identifier in the Permission Table

entry.title: Restricting User-Level Read and Delete Access - Datasphere
entry.content:
I have a scenario where I’m uploading data for multiple Consolidation Units into a local table in SAP Datasphere. I need to ensure that each user can only view and delete data related to the Consolidation Unit(s) assigned to them. How can I implement this restriction using Data Access Control in SAP Datasphere?

#SAP Datasphere @klaus-peter

entry.title: Using SAP CPI to Perform POST Calls on SAP Datasphere OData API
entry.content:
Hello Everyone,

In my current scenario, I need to perform both GET and POST operations on an OData API exposed from SAP Datasphere. Querying records works fine using OAuth 2.0 with the Authorization Code grant type.

Now, I have another use case where I need to push data from SAP CPI into Datasphere for integration purposes. While I know that data loading can be done using the JDBC adapter in CPI, I would prefer an API-based approach.

The key challenge I’m facing is around executing a POST request to insert records directly into Datasphere tables. Does Datasphere support inserting data into its tables via APIs, or is there a workaround required to achieve this?

If anyone has implemented this in a project, I would really appreciate your insights.

Thanks in advance!

entry.title: Datasphere not able to connect to Cloud connector
entry.content:
Hi Team, 

We have subscribed Datasphere sub account and trying to add backend systems. While i am trying to add systems getting below error. 

An error occurred while fetching container data.We can provide the following information to assist either you or an SAP engineer to solve the issue:

Correlation ID: c7242ca31c35cf0da69dc8fbcf002ceb
HTTP Status: 500 error
Error Code: connectionbrowse
Technical Message: Failed to fetch the data. Error in getDisConnectionChildren. Failed to get container children for /. Cause 0: request failed: rc=1, msg="Message: Opening connection to backend failed: There is no SAP Cloud Connector (SCC) connected to your subaccount matching the requested tunnel for subaccount \"a6fe4679-3ed9-4211-887e-4da2b8851867\" and SCC location ID, with default value, that is empty string or simply not configured. Check the configuration on SCC and cloud side.\nCode: RFC_COMMUNICATION_FAILURE" Code: 99999

BR,

Naresh.

entry.title: Datasphere: Using Inherited Standard Variables in Derive Value Variables
entry.content:
Hello,

I have an Analytic Model (B) built on top of another Analytic Model (A) with a standard variable for CALWEEK being inherited. In B, I would like to create a Derived Value variable that would map the inherited variable from A as a parameter for the lookup, but it's not available in the list. It's a bit strange to me that this is not allowed. Is it not possible to use inherited standard variables as mappings in other variables?

Regards,

Dimitar

entry.title: SAP Datasphere: SQL or Graphical Views?
entry.content:
Making an Educated Decision

In today’s data-driven world, SAP Datasphere empowers businesses to seamlessly connect, prepare, and manage their data. Among its many capabilities, views play a central role in combining local or remote tables, enriching datasets, and creating meaningful insights.

But when it comes to building these views, SAP Datasphere offers two powerful approaches: Graphical Views and SQL Views.

which one should you choose? Let’s break it down.

1. Understanding Views in SAP Datasphere

Views are essential components that allow you to:

  • Combine data from multiple sources (local or remote tables).
  • Link, filter, and enrich datasets.
  • Rename or remove columns to simplify models.
  • Add calculated columns and custom logic.

This flexibility makes views a cornerstone of data modeling in SAP Datasphere.

2. Understanding Graphical Views

Graphical Views in SAP Datasphere enable you to prepare and model data without requiring any prior knowledge of SQL. Using an intuitive drag-and-drop interface, both business users and non-technical professionals can easily create and manage views.

 

 

With graphical views, you can:

  • Seamlessly add and combine multiple data sources.
  • Join, filter, and enrich your datasets with just a few clicks.
  • Rearrange, rename, or exclude columns to simplify your models.
  • Create calculated columns and perform aggregations effortlessly.
  • Build unions and refine data flows visually.

If necessary, you can generate and display the corresponding SQL statement via the menu path Edit → Export → Preview SQL. This way, graphical views can be used as a template for the SQL views.

3. Understanding SQL Views

SQL Views in SAP Datasphere provide a powerful and flexible way to model data using SQLScript. They are ideal for scenarios that require advanced transformations, complex logic, and fine-grained control over your data.

 

With SQL Views, you can:

  • Gain full control over data transformations and modeling logic.
  • Utilize advanced SQL functions and implement conditional statements.
  • Integrate multiple layers of business rules directly into your data models.
  • Optimize queries and improve system performance.

SQL Views are typically preferred by developers and data engineers, as they offer the depth and flexibility needed for complex scenarios.

Best Use Cases:

  • When your data modeling involves complex transformations that go beyond the capabilities of graphical views.
  • For situations where performance optimization is a top priority.

When you need precise control over every detail of your SQL-based logic.

4. When to Combine Both: Mixed Scenarios

In some cases, the best solution is not choosing between the two but combining them:

  • Use Graphical Views to handle simpler joins and aggregations.
  • Enhance them by embedding SQL logic for advanced calculations.
  • Enrich functions written in SQLScript directly within the graphical interface.

This hybrid approach ensures scalability, flexibility, and performance optimization.

5. Key Differences Between Graphical and SQL Views

  • Graphical Views offer a visual, drag-and-drop interface designed for business users and non-technical teams. They simplify joins, filters, and aggregations without requiring SQL knowledge and are less error-prone.
  • SQL Views provide greater flexibility and advanced customization, ideal for developers and data engineers. With SQLScript, you can handle complex transformations, use subqueries, and apply window functions for optimized data modeling.
  • While Graphical Views are faster for beginners, SQL Views are often quicker, easier to maintain, and reusable for experienced developers.

6. Use Cases and Best Practices

  • For complex, evolving data models that require frequent updates, SQL Views are the better choice. They are easier to read, simpler to maintain, and more scalable over time.
  • If you currently rely on Graphical Views for these scenarios, consider migrating early. Although you can export graphical views to SQL, the generated code is often hard to read and requires manual adjustments.
  • When using SQL Views, follow best practices for readable SQLScript and optimized performance to ensure smooth maintenance.

Conclusion

Choosing between Graphical Views and SQL Views in SAP Datasphere depends on your business needs, team expertise, and data complexity.

  • If you want simplicity and speed, go for Graphical Views.

  • If you need advanced customization and performance control, SQL Views are your best bet.

  • And when in doubt? Mix both approaches to leverage the strengths of each.

By making an educated decision, you can optimize your data modeling process and unlock the full potential of SAP Datasphere.
